description: From Middle English shyngel, from Old English sċingul, a late variant of sċindel, from Proto-West Germanic *skindulā, borrowed from Late Latin scindula, from Latin scandula, from Proto-Indo-European *sked- (“to split, scatter”), from *sek- (“to cut”). Doublet of shindle.

entries.meaning: A small, thin piece of building material, often with one end thicker than the other, for laying in overlapping rows as a covering for the roof or sides of a building.
A rectangular piece of steel obtained by means of a shingling process involving hammering of puddled steel.
A small signboard designating a professional office; this may be both a physical signboard or a metaphoric term for a small production company (a production shingle).
examples: When [these attorneys] were born, in the early decades of the 19th century, being a lawyer meant putting out a shingle and representing your neighbors.

verbs.description: shingle (third-person singular simple present shingles, present participle shingling, simple past and past participle shingled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cover with small, thin pieces of building material, with shingles.
(transitive) To cut, as hair, so that the ends are evenly exposed all over the head, like shingles on a roof.
(transitive) To increase the storage density of (a hard disk) by writing tracks that partially overlap.

description: From dialectal French chingler (“to strap, whip”), from Latin cingula (“girt, belt”), from cingere (“to girt”).

entries.meaning: A punitive strap such as a belt.
(by extension) Any paddle used for corporal punishment.

verbs.description: shingle (third-person singular simple present shingles, present participle shingling, simple past and past participle shingled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, manufacturing) To hammer and squeeze material in order to expel cinder and impurities from it, as in metallurgy.

description: From Middle English shingel, chingel, singel (“gravel, pebbles”), cognate with Norwegian Bokmål singel (“pebble(s)”), Norwegian Nynorsk singel (“pebble(s)”), and North Frisian singel (“gravel”), imitative of the sound of water running over such pebbles.

entries.meaning: Small, smooth pebbles, as found on a beach.
examples: And naked shingles of the world.
